text: one reader says that morality based on
absolutes doesn't work and asked if I
have any favorite philosopher or source
of ethical values I'd have to say that
the philosopher who speaks to me the
most was my hero when I was a law
student at Oxford University somebody
had the chance to get to know a little
bit there that's sir isaiah berlin sir
isaiah berlin argued that we have a deep
human impulse to find one absolute moral
yardstick but in fact were fated to live
her life where there are many yard
sticks of things that are important of
real values and those yard sticks are in
commensurate and there are real
unpleasant trade-offs that we have to
draw that is just the problem with being
an adult and frankly that kind of
matches the confused difficult
cacophonous world in which I live where
I see a lot of things that I value
sometimes in conflict
the other thing that sir isaiah berlin
said that i think speaks to me is that
even if we acknowledge that we can make
mistakes that we may be that we may make
moral judgments that are erroneous that
it's still appropriate to act on them
and indeed it's important to do what we
think is right even if we acknowledge
the possibility that our moral judgments
will be mistaken for me it's a that's an
ethic that fits the world of 21st
century
